Article.Abstract: Hantavirus nucleocapsid protein (N) has been proven to induce highly protective immune responses in animal models. The knowledge on the mechanisms behind N-induced protection is still limited, although recent data suggest that both cellular and humoral immune responses are of importance. For a detailed B-cell epitope mapping of Puumala hantavirus (PUUV) N, we used recombinant N derivatives of the Russian strain CG18-20 and the Swedish strain Vranica/Hällnäs, as well as overlapping synthetic peptides corresponding to the Finnish prototype strain Sotkamo. The majority of a panel of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) reacted with proteins derived from all included PUUV strains demonstrating the antigenic similarity of these proteins. In line with previous results, the epitopes of most mAbs were mapped within the 80 N-terminal amino acids of N. The present study further revealed that the epitopes of four mAbs raised against native viral N were located within amino acids 14-45, whereas one mAb raised against recombinant N was mapped to amino acids 14-39. Differences between the reactivity of the PUUV strains Vranica/Hällnäs and CG18-20 N suggested the importance of amino acid position 35 for the integrity of the epitopes. In line with the patterns obtained by the truncated recombinant proteins, mapping by overlapping peptides (PEPSCAN) confirmed a complex recognition pattern for most analyzed mAbs. Together, the results revealed the existence of several, partially overlapping, and discontinuous B-cell epitopes. In addition, based on differences within the same competition group, novel epitopes were defined.
Article.ArticleTitle: Mapping of B-cell epitopes in the nucleocapsid protein of Puumala hantavirus.
Article.Affiliations: Swedish Institute for Infectious Disease Control, and Microbiology and Tumor Biology Center, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm. akelun@mbox.ki.se
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Antibodies, Monoclonal(immunology); Epitope Mapping(methods); Epitopes, B-Lymphocyte; Mice; Molecular Sequence Data; Nucleocapsid(chemistry; immunology); Puumala virus(immunology)

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This region is identical in the strains CD18-20 and Vranica/Hallnas of Puumala virus, except for a D35Y mutation in the latter. The accession provided here correponds to the Nucleocapsid protein of a representative strain of Puumala virus that contains the epitope sequence. The Nucleocapsid protein from CG18-20 strain is not available in the current protein databases.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: No details on the immunization protocol for the generation of this mouse mAb is provided. It was previously described in Zoller et al, 1993, J. Clin, Microbiol. 31: 1194.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: N protein fragments from strains CG18-20 and Vranica/Hallnass expressed as inserts in HBV core antigen showed that the mAb A1C5 recognized both proteins in the residues 14-39 region. That region is identical in both strains except for the D35Y mutation from CDG18-20 to Vranica/Hallnas. Other mAbs generated form infected bank voles, (1C12, 3E11, 4C3, 5A3) recognize the same fragment from CG18-20 but not form Vranica-Hallnas, implying residue 35 in their specific recognition.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: No details on the immunization protocol for the generation of mouse mAb A1C5 is provided. It was previously described in Zoller et al, 1993, J. Clin, Microbiol. 31: 1194. Bank vole antibodies were raised against the virus as described in Lundkvist et al, 1991, J. Gen. Virol., 72:2097.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Monoclonal murine antibody A1C5 raised against the N protein and monoclonal bank vole antibodies raised against Puumala virus, that were shown to recognize this epitopic region, are also shown to recognize the N protein in native ELISA.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: No details on the immunization protocol for the generation of the bank vole mAbs is provided. They were generated by heterohybridoma production from infected voles with mouse hybridoma Sp/2 cells as described in Lundkvist et al, 1991, J. Gen. Virol., 72:2097.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Monoclonal bank vole antibody/ies raised against Puumala virus, that were shown to recognize this epitopic region, are also shown to recognize the N protein in native ELISA.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: No details on the immunization protocol for the generation of the bank vole mAbs is provided. They were generated by heterohybridoma production from infected voles with mouse hybridoma Sp/2 cells.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: N-protein peptides from strain Sotkamo were used to map the epitopes recognized by bank vole mAbs. This fragment and the adjacent fragment 10-23, as well as other 4 disperse regions, are recognized by mAb 5E1.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: No details on the immunization protocol for the generation of the bank vole mAbs is provided. They were generated by heterohybridoma production from infected voles with mouse hybridoma Sp/2 cells.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: N-protein peptides from strain Sotkamo were used to map the epitopes recognized by bank vole mAbs. This fragment and the adjacent fragment 7-20, as well as other 4 disperse regions, are recognized by mAb 5E1.
